clinical_study.brief_title: Safe Limits in Saturation in the ICU (SLIM-study)
clinical_study.official_title: Safe Limits in Saturation in the ICU (SLIM-study)

brief_summary.textblock: A prospective study in the ICU in a university hospital in Amsterdam. The relationship between the oxygen saturation measured by pulse-oximetry and the arterial PaO2 is investigated in the general ICU population in order to investigate which transcutaneous saturation values are safe.

detailed_description.textblock: Supplemental oxygen is one of the most commonly prescribed therapies in the intensive care unit (ICU) in order to avoid tissue hypoxia. Oxygen is often administered superfluously. An increasing number of studies suggests harmful effects of supra-physiological PaO2 or 'hyperoxia'. Therefore, it is important to aim for PaO2-values within the physiological range. In the ICU the arterial oxygen concentration (measured as the partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) in arterial blood gas analysis) and oxygen saturation measured by pulse oximetry (SpO2) are used as targets of oxygenation. The partial pressure of oxygen is the gold standard in determining the oxygenation status of the patient, but SpO2-values are continuously available. In order to determine the SpO2-targets that are safe in avoiding both hyperoxia and hypoxia (as determined by PaO2) the correlation between PaO2 and SpO2 in critically ill patients will be investigated. Factors effecting this relationship are defined, such as peripheral blood flow and skin temperature. PaO2 measurements are routinely conducted multiple times a day as part of the regular care in the ICU. SpO2 is measured continuously as part of the regular care. When a routinely scheduled PaO2 value is measured the SpO2 will be written down.

primary_outcome.measure: Partial pressure of oxygen measured by arterial bloodgas analysis (mmHg)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Within the first 14 days of admission
primary_outcome.description: Blood gas sampling is part of the regular care at the intensive care unit. When a blood sample is taken, the partial pressure of oxygen is always measured and written down.

secondary_outcome.measure: Temperature difference between the lower arm and finger (degrees celsius)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Within the first 14 days of admission
secondary_outcome.description: During blood gas sampling, the temperature of the lower arm and index finger will be measured.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Within the first 14 days of admission
secondary_outcome.description: During blood gas sampling, the Peripheral Flow Index will be measured. The Peripheral Flow Index is the ratio of the pulsatile versus the nonpulsatile component of the pulse oximetry signal.

arm_group.description: Critically ill patients (18 years and older) on mechanically ventilation who have an arterial line and require bloodgasanalysis for medical reasons
Patients (18 years and older), who are presented to the Emergency Department, and require bloodgasanalysis for medical reasons
Patients (18 years and older) who visit the outpatient clinic of the pulmonary department for different pulmonary functional test and require bloodgasanalysis for medical reasons

study_pop.textblock: Patients on the Intensive Care Unit who require mechanical ventilation and have an arterial line

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- The patient must be admitted to the Intensive Care Unit
- The patient must be on mechanical ventilation at the time of blood sampling
- The patient must have an arterial line
- Oral informed consent mist be given to a legal representative
Exclusion Criteria:
- Therapeutic hypothermia
- Bilirubinemia > 20 µmol/l
- Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation
- Carboxyhemoglobin >1,5%
- Methemoglobin >1,5%
